story:
I am heading to Siem Reap, Cambodia, to volunteer my skills as a social worker specializing in trauma therapy and sex trafficking prevention for the Senhoa foundation.  www.senhoafoundation.org

In Siem Reap, many families live on $1.25 US per day by collecting recyclables from local garbage facilities.  This leaves them at risk for selling their children into prostitution.  Many sex workers do not receive any compensation and are held as slaves.  Those who have escaped this life are at a high risk for returning to the sex industry, as they do not have education or marketable skills.  SE Asia is a hub for sex tourism and virginity sales.

Victims of human sex trafficking experience severe physical and psychological trauma as a result of violence, rape, threats, addictions, and other means traffickers use to control their victims.  Survivors experience inability to express feelings, poor communication skills, inability to make friends, fear of adults/strangers, drug addiction, nightmares, flashbacks, depression and suicidal ideation.  Survivors may experience inability to dream and hope for the future, as they struggle to form an identity outside of as a sexual object.

Senhoa operates three programs:

  • The Lotus Kids Club to help educate families and prevent children from being sold into sex slavery
  • The Lotus House safehouse for women and girls rescued from the sex industry to receive rehabilitation and reintegration services
  • The Jewelry Life Skills program to teach vocational skills to women so that they are at less risk of being re-trafficked

Cambodia has only had two graduating social work classes -- EVER.  Many social workers in Cambodia lack formal training in social work and trauma therapy.  I will be helping to train Khmer social workers in evidence-based practices, building programming for the Lotus Kids Club, working directly with the community and families, and providing trauma therapy and consultation to the Lotus House. 

I received my MSW from the University of Denver Graduate School of Social Work, and am licensed in the state of Colorado.  I am a certified Trauma Release Exercises (TRE) Practitioner as well, and I am hoping to share this self-administered, self-regulated technique to release tension and trauma from the body and reduce symptoms of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.  For more information on TRE: www.traumaprevention.com


Where your contribution will go:

I am volunteering without a stipend and will be paying all of my own expenses.  The bare minimum for this trip will be approximately $6500.  

Cost of living (room and board) averages out to $20 per day.  $20 x 6 months = $3600

Round trip airfare = $1400-$2000

Travel insurance = $975

Business Visa = $300

Indiegogo charges 4% if my goal is met, and 9% if it is not.  I am setting my goal at the minimum to lower this expense.  I am planning on traveling to Thailand, Laos, Vietnam and Indonesia to offer free TRE workshops in my spare time, and this will be an additional expense.  If this venture is successful, I will be traveling to Kenya in late 2014 or 2015 to help build a similar program for sexual abuse survivors.  My "real" goal is $20,000 to cover two years of this work, with some time in between trips to come home to visit my incredibly supportive partner, John.  :)

story:
Hell and High Water - The Song


This song was originally written and recorded by T Graham Brown in 1986 and went to # 1 on the country charts in both the US and Canada

In 2005 I recorded my second album "Kentucky Fried Celtic" down in Kentucky with Grammy award winning producer, Mark Goodman.  He suggested this song would make a great addition to the album.  We recorded it with the help of several Grand Old Opry session players and the saxophone player who has played with the Memphis horns.

With the tragedy that has happened throughout Southern Alberta with severe flooding and numerous people being evacuated and or losing their homes, The lyrics of this song really embraces the hardship but also the coming together of communities to help their fellow neighbor.

If this song, this album, or my performance can at all help folks in Southern Alberta, please donate in hopes that in some small way, we can make a difference in peoples lives.


God Bless!

 

Rob Skeet

story:
Meet the Co-Owners

Joe Delgado is an ACE certified personal trainer, holds 2 master's degrees in Business and Human Resources, and Health Systems Administration and has over 15 years of experience in the fitness industry. He is passionate about wellness and educating athletes about competing at the elite level without the use of performance enhancing drugs. Joe holds many state and national records in drug-free powerlifting and enjoys being a mentor in the sport.

Jacques-Luis Nodar is an ACE certified personal trainer with over 15 years of experience in the fitness industry. He has enjoyed working in many facilities and with many different populations including youth groups, sports teams, and senior living facilities. He hopes to motivate people to achieve their wellness goals and lead a healthier, happier life.

Jacques-Luis and Joe have always had a dream to be able to offer a facility to the community where everyone feels welcomed, comfortable, and can achieve their health and wellness goals. They spent ten years purchasing equipment, continuing their education, improving their skills, and developing a business plan, to form Max Effort Training LLC.

Max Effort Training LLC

At Max Effort Training (MET), we are passionate about wellness. We truly care about helping each individual become healthier and happier. We provide a positive, supportive environment to help people achieve their goals and improve their lives overall. We pride ourselves on being flexible and adapting to the needs of each individual client. There is no "cookie cutter" generic programming at MET. Every program is customized and appropriate for the individual person.

Our client base ranges from kids fitness to senior fitness and everything in between. We take great pride in the fact that we can accommodate such a wide range of clientele. We love the diversity and the challenge that each individual client represents to us. Our fundamental values are those of hard work and positive energy. These are the main ingredients for success. We will look to challenge you in an appropriate fashion and have fun along the way!

We just recently moved into a new facility and are looking to expand our services not only to members but the community in general. We are looking for contributions to help us provide programming to meet the needs of the community. Funds will also help obtain equipment and help with other facility needs.  


What We Need & What You Get

Some examples of community programs that we are interested in providing are:

-Kids fitness

-Senior Fitness

-After School Lift and Learn

-Family Health Lifestyle and Nutrition

-Weight loss support groups and challenges

Some examples of facility needs are:

-Equipment to accommodate the needs of the clients

-Massage room furniture

-Assessment room equipment and setup

-Locker room furnishings

-Equipment to support future services (Chiropractic, Accupuncture, Physical Therapy, etc.)


The Impact

Your contributions will help support a company that has a proven track record in health and wellness. We are a self-funded, start-up company and your contribution will directly help change people's lives in a positive manner. In three short years, we have helped transform countless lives and our ultimate goal is to have a long-lasting, positive impact on the community.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to contribute, please share the word about our campaign to others. Indiegogo makes it easy by using the share tools. We truly care about helping people, and we need your help to be successful. Thank you so much for your time.

story:
Short Summary

Welcome!  Do you love the Lord?  Do you play golf?  Do you know anyone else who does?  If so, then you've come to the right place!

My name is Darrell Link (my friends call me "Link").  I'm the Inventor of the patented Cross Brush™, a golf club cleaning tool designed to:
  • Honor Christ
  • Hang from Your Golf Bag and
  • Improve Your Game
I created this project because I'd like your help taking this product from just a simple dream to a full reality that ultimately helps build God's kingdom.  I'm not a pastor or a deacon.  But I love the Lord; I've always wanted to be an entrepreneur & philanthropist; and I desire to do good things in the community.
This project isn't about me, though.  This new start-up exists for people who love Christ, love golf, and are excited about expressing their faith while playing the game they love.  To be more specific, our goal is to provide quality cross-shaped brushes that specifically benefit and inspire Christian golfers.  The Cross Brush actually helps you strike golf balls better, too!  Also, 10% of all proceeds will benefit faith-based initiatives such as the Fellowship of Christian Athletes (FCA)!


What's Needed & What You Get In Return

The funding goal is $5K, and every penny will be used to support this project. 

If you’re an avid golfer, a beginner, even a family member or friend of a golfer, I invite you to grow with what I refer to as 'The Cross Brush Concept.'  Your contributions will directly support future product development, professional website design, additional patents & trademarks, and tradeshow displays.

More importantly, you--or that special golfer in your life--will be inspired and empowered to spread God's word on the driving range, on the golf course, and at the clubhouse.  Simply latching/displaying your Cross Brush on your golf bag as a reminder of God's goodness is an option, too. 

 The Impact

Here's one example of how The Cross Brush can have a BIG impact. Imagine this:

A golfer completes a round of golf, returns to the clubhouse, and places his/her golf bag upright on the ground before heading to the 19th hole (usually a restaurant & bar at the golf course).  As the golfer does this, a person nearby notices something very unique about the golfer's bag (hanging from the golfer's bag is a cross-shaped brush that clearly honors Jesus Christ).  The two people engage in a conversation about the cross and its significance in the golfer's life.  By the end of the discussion the other person (maybe a golfer, maybe not) accepts Christ as his/her personal Savior.

Additionally, maintaining clean golf clubs—or “irons” as many clubs are called—is absolutely essential to every golfer’s success on the course.  Why?  Because clean grooves lead to much purer ball-striking, which usually translates into much lower scores; and that’s something every golfer wants. 

 

Risks & Challenges

This is a relatively new work in progress; that in and of itself is a challenge. However, I truly believe the unwavering faith, products, planning, and level of commitment that have gone into this project will produce something favorable in God's eyes.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people simply don't have the money to contribute to this campaign.  I can appreciate that.  Here are some other critical ways you can help:

  • Make some noise about this "golf ministry" campaign!
  • Tell your pastor, your congregation, your family members, and friends.
  • Also, use Indiegogo's share tools to help spread the word via social media.

One of the biggest complements you can give is a referral.  Thank you!

Product Dimensions:

7-1/2" x  3-3/4"  x  .5"

story:
Русская Версия/Russian Version

Children are our future.

306 students of Khndzoresk village school want to have clean restrooms and use running water to wash their hands. Help them make their dream come true!

Summary

The kids in Khnzdoresk village haven't had clean restrooms and running water for years. ArmNet LA, in cooperation with Anna Astvatsaturian Turcotte, is aiming to rebuild all restrooms for the 306 students of the school and a few dozen staff. Would you send your kid to school with this restroom?

Neither would we. Let's do something about it!

The Project

The main goal of the project is to raise $25,000 by Summer 2015. Upon successful  funding of the project, an ArmNet representative will supervise the work of completely rebuilding 7 bathrooms in the village school. With your help, we can bring clean, running water, working sinks and clean toilets to the children of Khndzoresk.

Implementation of the project will help create jobs and secure a better future for generations ahead. By funding this project, you will help not only 306 children but the whole Syunik region.

About Khndzoresk

Khndzoresk is a village of about 2200 people located east of the city of Goris in Syunik province of Armenia. It is most widely known for its centuries-old caves and 160m long suspended bridge, built by its own residents. The village has rich history and played an important role in the liberation of the region. It falls upon our shoulders to show our brave ancestors that their efforts were not in vain.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute at the moment - we understand. Don't feel bad though, there are other ways you can help! Share this campaign with your friends and join our group page - ArmNet LA. We will be happy to see you!

Дети - наше будущее.

306 учеников из села Хндзореск мечтают о рабочих туалетах и чистой проточной воде. Давайте поможем осуществить их мечту!


Краткое Описание

Дети из села Хндзореск уже многие годы не имеют доступа к рабочим туалетам и чистой проточной воде в своей школе. Организация ArmNet LA, в сотрудничестве с Анной Аствацатурян-Туркотт, стремится реконструировать все туалеты для 306 учеников и нескольких десятков учителей школы Хнздореск. Вы бы отправили своего ребенка в школу с такими туалетами? Давайте поможем им!


Проект

Главная цель проекта собрать 25.000$ до лета этого года. При удачном сборе средств, представитель органиции ArmNet проконтролирует полную реконструкцию 7 туалетов школы. Только с Вашей помощью мы сможем дать детям Хндзореска чистую проточную воду и новые раковины и унитазы.

Реализация этого проекта создаст рабочие места и поможет обеспечить надежное будущее на долгие года. Помогая этому проекту, Вы помогаете не только 306 детям одной школы, но и всей провинции Сюник.


О Хндзореске

Хнздореск - поселок с населением около 2200 жителей, находящийся недалеко от Гориса. Более всего он известен своими древними пещерами и 160-метровым подвесным мостом, построенным самими жителями. Деревня Хндзореск богата своей историей и играла немаловажную роль в освобождении этого региона от вражеских завоевателей. На нас легла ответственность не пасть лицом в грязь и доказать, что усилия наших предков не были напрасными.


Другие Способы Помощи

Если Вы не можете помочь материально - не беда. Просто поделитись этим проектом в соцеальных сетях и вступайте в нашу группу. Мы будем Вам благодарны за все!
story_txt:
Русская Версия/Russian Version
Children are our future.
306 students of Khndzoresk village school want to have clean restrooms and use running water to wash their hands. Help them make their dream come true!
Summary
The kids in Khnzdoresk village haven't had clean restrooms and running water for years. ArmNet LA, in cooperation with Anna Astvatsaturian Turcotte, is aiming to rebuild all restrooms for the 306 students of the school and a few dozen staff. Would you send your kid to school with this restroom?Neither would we. Let's do something about it!


The Project
The main goal of the project is to raise $25,000 by Summer 2015. Upon successful  funding of the project, an ArmNet representative will supervise the work of completely rebuilding 7 bathrooms in the village school. With your help, we can bring clean, running water, working sinks and clean toilets to the children of Khndzoresk.

Implementation of the project will help create jobs and secure a better future for generations ahead. By funding this project, you will help not only 306 children but the whole Syunik region.

About Khndzoresk

Khndzoresk is a village of about 2200 people located east of the city of Goris in Syunik province of Armenia. It is most widely known for its centuries-old caves and 160m long suspended bridge, built by its own residents. The village has rich history and played an important role in the liberation of the region. It falls upon our shoulders to show our brave ancestors that their efforts were not in vain.



    Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute at the moment - we understand. Don't feel bad though, there are other ways you can help! Share this campaign with your friends and join our group page - ArmNet LA. We will be happy to see you!

story:
Our Environmental Commitment

"Together, we can reduce waste."

 

Creator's Message

Hi Backers! I am Sharon Cho, founder of Travel Friend LLC,  entrepreneur and a mom to 3 wonderful children. 

When I was on a business trip to Seoul, S. Korea earlier this year, I was introduced to a newly developed mask filter called nano fiber.  It is highly advanced nano textile technology used to produce nano fiber filter that is thin and has high breathability.  It has been tested, proven, and patent registered in S. Korea for the specific use on making reusable face masks.  I HAD to experience it myself! So, I got to work.  We gathered data and tests on nanofiber filter, designed and produced prototype and samples.  

I immediately tested it myself.  I walked around the city, ran around the streets, had meetings with my team and I knew right then that there are no other masks like this one.  It's not only comfortable and breathable, it protects us from airborne particles and microparticles. I had to share it with my family and friends.  The feedback was fanatical!  They all wanted more for THEIR family and friends.  So I thought, why not bring it to the rest of the world!?  We all deserve some normalcy during this unprecedented time. 

Thank you so much for taking your time to read my campaign.  Please do not hesitate to SHARE with your FAMILY and FRIENDS and your COMMUNITY!  Stay safe!

Sharon Cho

 

 

 

 

READY TO SHIP

story:
Youtuber's Review

 

 

 

Standing or sitting for long periods of time naturally encourages our bodies to find a comfortable position. As obvious as this sounds, comfortable positions eventually cause a threat to our spinal health. If you’re currently experiencing backache, shoulder discomfort, a stiff neck or fatigue with unknown causes, it is highly likely they are due to poor posture.

The pressure put on the back from a slouched posture amounts up to a maximum of 600lbs. Because the weight is not dispersed to the spine evenly, The surrounding muscles become even more cramped up and stiff. Bad posture sets in, it’s hard to return to the original state.

So Master Fit created Balancenap,

a product that helps you get over all those hurdles.

 

 

The body is made of a chain structure where everything is connected to each other and is in harmony through cooperation with stability and mobility.

If there is a problem in one spot, there is already a problem with the body’s balance, so overall management is very important rather than spot treatment.

Balancenap is a  total whole-body healthcare tool combining the features of body correction as well as massage and exercise done through the hands of a professional.

Balancenap is a total whole-body care correction tool created for office workers who stand or sit for a long time and for people who routinely feel backaches, shoulder discomfort, stiff neck, etc. even while being completely still.

It can be used easily in the desired area by anyone and straightens the spine through simple movements. It will help blood circulation in the neck, waist, back, pelvis, and more to restore normal angles through consistent use and will train core muscles that are in charge of key functions in our bodies.

 

Starex evermoin ABS and ABF-0200HF, which are safe materials used in Balancenap, maintain excellent antibacterial properties even in various living environments, having an antibacterial growth rate of 99.9% or more and an excellent antifungal ability, so they can be applied to various household products to maintain top hygiene.

In addition, the Starex evermoin ABS, ABF-0200HF adds excellent weather resistance and UV stability, allowing the product to be used as new, with little physical degradation and color change over time. In addition, with strict international safety certification for food, health care, and toxicity, Evermoin is an antibacterial solution that can be applied on a wide variety of everyday items that require clean and safe materials.

 

The ideal angle is 30-35 degrees for neck, 40 degrees for back, and 45 degrees for waist. Just by putting Balancenap on an uncomfortable part and lying on it, it will facilitate the flow of fluid through a normal spinal angle and reduce nerve compression.

Simply by rolling left and right in the lying position you will relax the muscles that have been knotted for some time and improve core muscle function, as Balancenap is a piece of specialized equipment developed by a team of sports medicine doctors to help you maintain a healthy body without the yo-yo effect of re-clumping muscles.

 

Balancenap has superior features and functionality compared to similar product groups.

For example, a Foam Roller has various uses in massage, stretching, and exercise, but as it can overstrain the wrist and neck, there’s a high risk of getting secondary injury if you fail to keep balance.

Similarly, Ballance makes it hard for you to maintain balance and the bumps embedded in too deep may cause injuries.

Moreover, other similar product groups have distinct uses for a single body part such as the neck, spine, waist or pelvis, which decreases usability and creates an economic burden to purchase many products for whole-body care.

To provide reasonable features and performance, Balancenap was planned with the concept of total whole-body care from the very beginning of the research and development process, and has been made into an all-in-one item that can be used for all purposes, including massage, stretching, exercise, and body correction, in the easiest way possible.

 

 

 

*  In some regions, additional customs fee may be charged during delivery. Customs fee is paid by the purchaser.

 

From initial planning that began in 2017, to headrest development in ’19, design completion in ’20, and today’s Indiegogo funding, Balancenap has gone through various trial and error phases and difficulties including sketch, design, 2D & 3D design, working mock-up, mold-making, and sample testing.

Because it’s a product that directly affects physical health, we are keeping a close watch and meticulously inspecting the Balancenap process in person to help backers feel at their best. when using Balancenap. Through such efforts, we’re giving our all to prevent any defects in Balancenap.

There were external factors in which we could mass-produce with OEM factories in China to lower the unit cost, make the product easily, and sell more, but we didn’t want to leave any room for shortcomings in a tool managing the body, which is more precious than anything else. At last, we overcame all of these difficulties and finished the final sample production, and we are now able to present the finest product to our backers.

 

 

 

We established a U.S corporation in New York to launch on Indiegogo and went through 8 prototypes to design and finally develop the Balancenap.

We have made a contract with a local warehouse in the U.S. to reduce the shipping cost for backers. We guarantee that you can trust the product quality as Balancenap is 100% produced and manufactured in South Korea. This allows us to promise you fast shipping and inexpensive distribution costs.

We are past the prototype stage for the Balancenap. We’ve also inspected the product with hundreds of testers, so we are ready for the production stage.

We’re prepared for the production to begin the day after the campaign successfully ends. We were able to complete the next level “Balancenap”based on the evaluation and advice from the backers who showed interest and pledged. Thus, we promise to complete production and shipping within our promised time frame.

 

Warranty Period: 1 year since the date of receiving the reward

After-sales service regulations: 1:1 replacement is available when identifying the product defect within 7 days since receiving it (replacement for faulty parts, damage, form and functional abnormalities / due to the nature of eco-friendly material, there may be wrinkles on the elastic material of the acupressure board, and a gap may occur in the body part that combines without adhesive, but it is not a defect if the gap is 2mm or smaller.)

After-sales service is unavailable when: repair and reclamation cannot be done due to the user’s intentional or negligent act, even if it’s within the warranty period

How to request after-sales service: if you request to the below email with specific details on the defect, it will be processed after the maker provides an accurate explanation.

Where to request after-sales service: inquire the maker (support@balancenap.com)

story:
Please note: some events depicted are graphic in nature. Please take care in reading.

My wife and I started with one of those picture-perfect stories: met by happenstance on the internet to fall in love, young, energetic people out to conquer life excitedly with their college education and the will of God. Started the family, bought the house, pounded down debt, and started saving up for a rainy day. We had no idea that a rainy day could last so long.

When we decided to have our youngest child, Rowan, it was a long struggle. We tried and tried to have a little sibling for our fun and energetic son Ryland, but things weren't working out. It was recommended that we either use medical assistance to get pregnant or officially end the capability for pregnancy for the health of my wife when we suddenly learned that she was pregnant. The pregnancy itself was a blessing and went by without any issues, except for the fact that an ovarian cyst was growing along with my son. In early May, our ten-pound baby was to be delivered, and an almost ten-pound cyst was present as well.  Our bouncing baby boy was born completely healthy though. 

When the doctors did the c-section to bring our son into the world, as well as remove the cyst, the cyst ruptured. I was rushed out of the room with our new boy in my arms so that the doctors could finish taking care of my wife. As I sat there with my little boy, those few hours seemed like days. No doctor was available to tell me if my wife was okay, and I had no idea if the cyst rupture was serious or not. The cyst turned out to be non-harmful after lab testing.  But while I was waiting for her to come out, I snuggled our new boy and prayed he would know his mother. She eventually came out, but it was a scary few hours.

Our family continued as most would after a birth, learning new methods and getting to know how everyone worked together as a family. Soon, however, my wife Renee began having issues. At three weeks postpartum, she developed her first major fever of 105. She would get sick, get antibiotics, get better, then drop right back down to being sick. After two weeks Renee developed bilateral sciatica and she was unable to move. It became frustratingly repetitive as every time we went to the emergency room, we constantly were told, "oh, it's just an infection, here's some antibiotics" to turn around and do it again. As my wife got weaker and things became overwhelming, we took a vacation from my job in Virginia to visit our nearest family in Missouri for a bit of a respite and healing.

The night we got to Missouri, however, Renee got sick again, this time to the point she had to be admitted to the hospital. They stated that the infection she had was so bad it had gotten into her bloodstream. She was septic with pseudomonas and enterococcus fecalis. She needed immediate IV antibiotics. Our vacation and relaxation immediately turned into juggling our two little boys and supporting my wife, scared out of her mind in the hospital, all alone unless I was able to go. She wasn't getting better, and I was running out of vacation time. We had no choice: I had to drive back to Virginia, leaving my kids in my wife's mother's care, and my sick wife in the hospital, unsure if I would ever see her again.

When my wife finally got better a month later, I drove back, picked her up, and headed back to Virginia. Halfway through Kentucky, though, she got worse again, and we had to stop. Another emergency room overnight, another "it's just an infection", another antibiotic. Another disheartening unknown answer to everything. On the way back into town in Virginia, I had no chance but to drop the kids at the babysitter, drop my wife at the emergency room, and run off to work. I had literally exhausted every other option.

At the hospital, my wife was being told yet again that she was having an infection, here's some antibiotics. Just a few weeks earlier, she had been told at a clinic that she must be drug seeking to seek medical help so often in a short period of time.  By now it was July, and Renee was fed up and at her wit's end.  She told the doctors she would not leave the hospital until further testing was done on her kidneys, as she felt she had a stone stuck somewhere, or a kidney infection.  They agreed to a CT scan, where they discovered a multitude of kidney stones and a kidney infection! Pregnancy and ovarian cysts can mess with a body, and this one had done a number on her kidneys. She was sent to a kidney specialist that week. The kidney specialist said, "you know, that infection can effect your heart. You should see a cardiologist just to be safe." She was referred and visited them one week later. The results came the next morning.  My wife went in for the results and was met with information she never thought she would hear: that she had 48 to 72 hours to live. The infection that we had been fighting for months had infested her heart, eating away at her aortic valve. She had lost most of it, with a broccoli-shaped chunk hanging onto what was left. It was obvious that my wife would need open heart surgery to keep her alive. The big catch was they had put a clock on her life, but they couldn't operate until antibiotics had cleared up her bloodstream, while too much cleaning could cut the stem of the broccoli, letting a giant clot of infection head straight to her brain.

 

Renee lost the entire summer of 2011, as she needed to stay in quarantine as she battled this disease. She was laid off due to restructuring the following week from her long-term employment position she had advanced in.  Since she was so ill, she was unable to look for employment and she ended up being under doctor orders for approximately 90 days.  This prevented our ability for her to claim unemployment.  As she was laying in a bed dying, we craved family time, and I was dashing between work, home, and caring for my wife, unsure of the future. My wife and I had a three month emergency fund. We made it last 14 months and several friends and family came along side of us to fill in gaps as they were able, during this battle. 

Then there was insurance. Her workplace had let her go, and offered a COBRA plan at nearly $800/month. My wife obviously needed insurance right then. When calling around to insurance agencies at the time, "pre-existing condition" translated to "no way we are going to insure you." My only choice? Insure her at $800/mo on our already halved income since my wife obviously couldn't work, with no additional unemployment income either.

A summer passes, and Renee makes it home after open-heart surgery. Now, if you remember, it's time to take care of those kidney stones that were found before the heart surgery even started. After a few minor procedures to plan for stone removal procedures, Renee was scheduled to have a tube placed in her kidney through her back, in order to remove a large stone during the main surgery.  However, the doctor deemed that the tube had been placed "inopportunely." Translation: they couldn't get anything. An entire surgery (on a woman on blood thinners for life) was useless. We had to wait for her to heal up, bring her home, then wait to start again.

We didn't make it, though. After a week of healing in the hospital, we returned home. In the middle of the night, Renee called for help from the bathroom, and I find her. The toilet was nearly black with blood. We call an ambulance and she was rushed to the emergency room with a medic on board.  After many hours of frantic unsurity, we find that that tube that had been placed in the wrong area had nicked her renal artery. Blood was flowing through there, dropping into her kidneys, clotting up and forcing out her urethra. She was bleeding to death from the inside, and given 24 to 48 hours to live.

From the trauma bay in the ER, she was rushed to a local specialist hospital resulting in two overnight emergency surgeries and sixteen blood transfusions.  A coil stent was placed in her renal artery, saving her but permanently killing a quarter of her kidney to stave off the blood flow. Also lost: another couple months of healing, as Coumadin patients sometimes require extra time in the hospital post-op. My wife laments to this day her142 days in the hospital. Although she made some wonderful friends in nurses and medical team members, her boys needed her home. I was being the best Dad I could, but these boys needed their mother. Renee underwent several procedures to have the remaining stones removed surgically.  It was discovered that each of the stones was infected with the bloodstream infection mentioned before, so she remained with a picc line most of this time.  She now has only two stones left on board.  One is so large, it cannot be removed, as it is embedded into her kidney wall.  She was told she would need a transplant to be stone free, but this is not necessary for her survival.  Due to the prolonged exposure to the infection in her bloodstream, she now has a permanently damaged spleen, thus rendering it useless and unable to aid in staving off simple sinus or respiratory infections. This has resulted in additional hospital stays and medication changes.

I am blessed to have my wife with us. She is a strong, creative, woman and wonderful mother. I would go through all of this a hundred times if it were necessary to keep her in my life. But the resulting firestorm of financial distress has pulled us under. If not for the will of God, the charity of the church, and the friends who came alongside of us, we would be nowhere. They have kept us alive through it all, but our finances only stretch so thin. 

We had always wanted to move to the Midwest to live near family, however, due to financial issues from these events, it became necessary to leave our home and move to Missouri, taking a big hit financially and having to take part of our mortgage with us.  We appreciate all that the financial institutions in Virginia allowed us to do, in order to leave the area, even though we are really struggling.  We are currently living in the same house as my in-laws. As for jobs, Medicaid regulations have changed. For qualified candidates in social work positions that we have experience in, you now need a master's degree to do jobs that we have 12 years of experience in.  My wife's weakened state prevents her from getting a job, let alone by the time we would pay for a sitter and gas to get her to work, we would use most of the money and not be any further ahead in addition to all of the weekly medical expenses still looming.  I've taken a great job, but it pays less than what I was getting in Virginia and insuring my family would literally take 90% of my check. We're currently trying to figure out if the Affordable Healthcare Act can help us, since we cannot afford my work-provided insurance.  When applying for the AHA, we were told we don't make enough to qualify for the subsidies, kicking us into Medicaid status, but it's difficult to find specialists around this area that my wife needs to survive that accept Medicaid.

There are major big bills that we face. The largest one being the cost of insurance.  We are currently still paying $800/month, which is going on a credit card we opened for this reason, as we have no other means to pay it. We still have excellent credit, but we are concerned this will change. As I mentioned earlier, we shopped around, but pre-existing conditions made no company available to help my wife. As of right now, since we can no longer put insurance on our credit card, Renee could be uninsured as of January 1, unless the AHA comes through. 

We estimate that we have hundreds of thousands, if not a potential million dollars worth of doctor bills, with no end in sight. We have applied for financial aid with the hospitals and clinics who have provided care, and are waiting on some of the answers still.  My wife will need constant care with weekly coumadin clinic blood checks and monthly medication for the rest of her life. We have powered through many a financial hardship before this: by following the advice of Dave Ramsey, we had made a solid start to our little family. Now, we survive paycheck to paycheck. While we see a future where our bills are paid off, every time one of these $10 or $25/month bills gets close to paid off, another illness throws three more on the pile. We feel our budgeting expertise can get us stable again, but we have to get out of this hole first.

Renee's not out of the woods yet, either. A messed up Coumadin level has led to two visits to the hospital since, one for a heart attack and another resulting in a Thermal Ablation to prevent excess bleeding. She received four more blood transfusions as well.  Two more hospitals, two more reams of specialists, two more rounds of "minimum payments" that are becoming the maximum part of our income.

My work mates have led me here to indiegogo.com. I've researched and found many worthwhile causes that I wish I could contribute to. Without a doubt, I appreciate the time you have taken to listen to our story. Any contributions you can make to help soften the blow we have suffered would be greatly appreciated. No matter what, I have my wife and children. God has walked alongside us and to those who have supported us this long couple years, THANK YOU! If it weren't for the amazing team of doctors who were up to the challenge of saving her thrice from near-death experiences, my children would have a completely different life than they have today, blessed with their mother's presence. That's all I really need. Thanks again, and God bless.

What We Need and What You Get

  • We've set our goal at $50,000, which is primarily to get us a little breathing room, but as I stated earlier we have enough debt to be handing some down to our children if we do this on our own. Whether we miss, meet, or exceed our goal, every penny will go toward relieving the medical bills in front of us and maintaining my wife's regular doctor expenses.
  • A local agency, Rising Abilities, is processing some rewards that will be added on to the program as we go along. Keep your eyes on this spot for more information!

The Impact

Honestly, I'm confident that the future impact of this campaign will go beyond what I could ever imagine. Ryland and Rowan are wonderful children, and getting past this heavy debt will impact their future and allow them to see the goodness inherent in the world, helping them be better people as they grow. It will allow a wonderful woman who fought long and hard for her life to continue so she could raise these children do just that without the constant stigma of facing an unending pile of bills. Every person we've ever told this story to has shared their heart that they don't know how so much could happen to one family and we still have the strength that we do: I'm truly amazed that Renee is still standing after all of this. Every penny placed toward this campaign will help us live a more normal life. We aren't out to get rich on this. If it raises a dollar, we will be honored.

Other Ways You Can Help

We have been blessed with the joy of being together as a family, and the funds raised here will help a lot, but we know not everybody hitting this site will be able to contribute. Here's what you can do to help:

  • Pray, Pray, Pray! We feel that spiritual support will do wonders: miracles can happen financially, and your heavenly requests can bring us emotional support as well.
  • Spread the word at this site. Tweet us, Facebook us, Google Plus us, whatever it takes. If you can spread the word, the ones who can fund will find out! I've set up an official Facebook page at this link: https://www.facebook.com/johnsonheartofthefamily I will be adding pics and general goodwill information on how the campaign is going as well as general Johnson family goodness. Feel free to like us!
story_txt:
Please note: some events depicted are graphic in nature. Please take care in reading.My wife and I started with one of those picture-perfect stories: met by happenstance on the internet to fall in love, young, energetic people out to conquer life excitedly with their college education and the will of God. Started the family, bought the house, pounded down debt, and started saving up for a rainy day. We had no idea that a rainy day could last so long.When we decided to have our youngest child, Rowan, it was a long struggle. We tried and tried to have a little sibling for our fun and energetic son Ryland, but things weren't working out. It was recommended that we either use medical assistance to get pregnant or officially end the capability for pregnancy for the health of my wife when we suddenly learned that she was pregnant. The pregnancy itself was a blessing and went by without any issues, except for the fact that an ovarian cyst was growing along with my son. In early May, our ten-pound baby was to be delivered, and an almost ten-pound cyst was present as well.  Our bouncing baby boy was born completely healthy though.  When the doctors did the c-section to bring our son into the world, as well as remove the cyst, the cyst ruptured. I was rushed out of the room with our new boy in my arms so that the doctors could finish taking care of my wife. As I sat there with my little boy, those few hours seemed like days. No doctor was available to tell me if my wife was okay, and I had no idea if the cyst rupture was serious or not. The cyst turned out to be non-harmful after lab testing.  But while I was waiting for her to come out, I snuggled our new boy and prayed he would know his mother. She eventually came out, but it was a scary few hours.Our family continued as most would after a birth, learning new methods and getting to know how everyone worked together as a family. Soon, however, my wife Renee began having issues. At three weeks postpartum, she developed her first major fever of 105. She would get sick, get antibiotics, get better, then drop right back down to being sick. After two weeks Renee developed bilateral sciatica and she was unable to move. It became frustratingly repetitive as every time we went to the emergency room, we constantly were told, "oh, it's just an infection, here's some antibiotics" to turn around and do it again. As my wife got weaker and things became overwhelming, we took a vacation from my job in Virginia to visit our nearest family in Missouri for a bit of a respite and healing.The night we got to Missouri, however, Renee got sick again, this time to the point she had to be admitted to the hospital. They stated that the infection she had was so bad it had gotten into her bloodstream. She was septic with pseudomonas and enterococcus fecalis. She needed immediate IV antibiotics. Our vacation and relaxation immediately turned into juggling our two little boys and supporting my wife, scared out of her mind in the hospital, all alone unless I was able to go. She wasn't getting better, and I was running out of vacation time. We had no choice: I had to drive back to Virginia, leaving my kids in my wife's mother's care, and my sick wife in the hospital, unsure if I would ever see her again.When my wife finally got better a month later, I drove back, picked her up, and headed back to Virginia. Halfway through Kentucky, though, she got worse again, and we had to stop. Another emergency room overnight, another "it's just an infection", another antibiotic. Another disheartening unknown answer to everything. On the way back into town in Virginia, I had no chance but to drop the kids at the babysitter, drop my wife at the emergency room, and run off to work. I had literally exhausted every other option. At the hospital, my wife was being told yet again that she was having an infection, here's some antibiotics. Just a few weeks earlier, she had been told at a clinic that she must be drug seeking to seek medical help so often in a short period of time.  By now it was July, and Renee was fed up and at her wit's end.  She told the doctors she would not leave the hospital until further testing was done on her kidneys, as she felt she had a stone stuck somewhere, or a kidney infection.  They agreed to a CT scan, where they discovered a multitude of kidney stones and a kidney infection! Pregnancy and ovarian cysts can mess with a body, and this one had done a number on her kidneys. She was sent to a kidney specialist that week. The kidney specialist said, "you know, that infection can effect your heart. You should see a cardiologist just to be safe." She was referred and visited them one week later. The results came the next morning.  My wife went in for the results and was met with information she never thought she would hear: that she had 48 to 72 hours to live. The infection that we had been fighting for months had infested her heart, eating away at her aortic valve. She had lost most of it, with a broccoli-shaped chunk hanging onto what was left. It was obvious that my wife would need open heart surgery to keep her alive. The big catch was they had put a clock on her life, but they couldn't operate until antibiotics had cleared up her bloodstream, while too much cleaning could cut the stem of the broccoli, letting a giant clot of infection head straight to her brain. Renee lost the entire summer of 2011, as she needed to stay in quarantine as she battled this disease. She was laid off due to restructuring the following week from her long-term employment position she had advanced in.  Since she was so ill, she was unable to look for employment and she ended up being under doctor orders for approximately 90 days.  This prevented our ability for her to claim unemployment.  As she was laying in a bed dying, we craved family time, and I was dashing between work, home, and caring for my wife, unsure of the future. My wife and I had a three month emergency fund. We made it last 14 months and several friends and family came along side of us to fill in gaps as they were able, during this battle.  Then there was insurance. Her workplace had let her go, and offered a COBRA plan at nearly $800/month. My wife obviously needed insurance right then. When calling around to insurance agencies at the time, "pre-existing condition" translated to "no way we are going to insure you." My only choice? Insure her at $800/mo on our already halved income since my wife obviously couldn't work, with no additional unemployment income either.A summer passes, and Renee makes it home after open-heart surgery. Now, if you remember, it's time to take care of those kidney stones that were found before the heart surgery even started. After a few minor procedures to plan for stone removal procedures, Renee was scheduled to have a tube placed in her kidney through her back, in order to remove a large stone during the main surgery.  However, the doctor deemed that the tube had been placed "inopportunely." Translation: they couldn't get anything. An entire surgery (on a woman on blood thinners for life) was useless. We had to wait for her to heal up, bring her home, then wait to start again.We didn't make it, though. After a week of healing in the hospital, we returned home. In the middle of the night, Renee called for help from the bathroom, and I find her. The toilet was nearly black with blood. We call an ambulance and she was rushed to the emergency room with a medic on board.  After many hours of frantic unsurity, we find that that tube that had been placed in the wrong area had nicked her renal artery. Blood was flowing through there, dropping into her kidneys, clotting up and forcing out her urethra. She was bleeding to death from the inside, and given 24 to 48 hours to live.From the trauma bay in the ER, she was rushed to a local specialist hospital resulting in two overnight emergency surgeries and sixteen blood transfusions.  A coil stent was placed in her renal artery, saving her but permanently killing a quarter of her kidney to stave off the blood flow. Also lost: another couple months of healing, as Coumadin patients sometimes require extra time in the hospital post-op. My wife laments to this day her142 days in the hospital. Although she made some wonderful friends in nurses and medical team members, her boys needed her home. I was being the best Dad I could, but these boys needed their mother. Renee underwent several procedures to have the remaining stones removed surgically.  It was discovered that each of the stones was infected with the bloodstream infection mentioned before, so she remained with a picc line most of this time.  She now has only two stones left on board.  One is so large, it cannot be removed, as it is embedded into her kidney wall.  She was told she would need a transplant to be stone free, but this is not necessary for her survival.  Due to the prolonged exposure to the infection in her bloodstream, she now has a permanently damaged spleen, thus rendering it useless and unable to aid in staving off simple sinus or respiratory infections. This has resulted in additional hospital stays and medication changes.I am blessed to have my wife with us. She is a strong, creative, woman and wonderful mother. I would go through all of this a hundred times if it were necessary to keep her in my life. But the resulting firestorm of financial distress has pulled us under. If not for the will of God, the charity of the church, and the friends who came alongside of us, we would be nowhere. They have kept us alive through it all, but our finances only stretch so thin.  We had always wanted to move to the Midwest to live near family, however, due to financial issues from these events, it became necessary to leave our home and move to Missouri, taking a big hit financially and having to take part of our mortgage with us.  We appreciate all that the financial institutions in Virginia allowed us to do, in order to leave the area, even though we are really struggling.  We are currently living in the same house as my in-laws. As for jobs, Medicaid regulations have changed. For qualified candidates in social work positions that we have experience in, you now need a master's degree to do jobs that we have 12 years of experience in.  My wife's weakened state prevents her from getting a job, let alone by the time we would pay for a sitter and gas to get her to work, we would use most of the money and not be any further ahead in addition to all of the weekly medical expenses still looming.  I've taken a great job, but it pays less than what I was getting in Virginia and insuring my family would literally take 90% of my check. We're currently trying to figure out if the Affordable Healthcare Act can help us, since we cannot afford my work-provided insurance.  When applying for the AHA, we were told we don't make enough to qualify for the subsidies, kicking us into Medicaid status, but it's difficult to find specialists around this area that my wife needs to survive that accept Medicaid. story:
Hello everyone, my name is Maria Baeza. I am starting a campaign for my best friend's son, Eloy Velasquez who is currently battling cancer at the young age of five.

This is what happened: (As narrated by Eloy's Mother, Yolanda)

On April 22nd, 2013 Eloy was taken to the doctor to get his annual check up and vaccines to prepare him for kindergarten this fall. After over an hour wait Dr. Canete came in to examine Eloy, she said that on his right side she noticed it felt firm, I then asked her what that could mean? she responded "it could be an enlarged liver, or he could just be constipated". Then she said she was not worried about it and dissmissed the whole topic, and off she went. Im sure you can imagine the confusion that went through my mind, I trusted this Doctor and I expected that as a proffessional if she was uncertain would do the right thing and order an x-ray or body scan of some sort. But that was not the case, I went home that day feeling very uncomfortable and disgusted of these "doctors".

In the two weeks that followed I noticed Eloy had not been himself, sleeping more, loss of appetite, fever, I began to worry.

It was May 1st, 2013 when the nightmare began after an Emergency room visit, and numerous test and scans, only verified that Eloy's firm liver was not Enlarged, but they had found what looked like a malignant tumor (cancer). Our hearts dropped, and we felt so devastated. Eloy was then admitted for 5 days for further testing and a Biopsy of the tumor. The doctors reassured us it was necessary, that way they would know how to treat him.
Its been 2 months since then, we have learned a whole new language of medical terms and we have managed to get a grip and remain strong and positive for Eloy. He is teaching us a lot through this journey, he remains brave and strong even after enduring long hours of chemotherapy. We are so proud of him but at the same time it breaks our hearts, because he should just be a healthy normal 5yr old with no worries. We try to take care of our children the best way we know how, but sometimes there's just things that we as parents cant understand. We pray everyday that God guide the specialist and doctors in making the right decisions for our sons well being, and we pray for strength to help him get through this fight....

My friend, Yolanda is a stay at home mom and needs all the help she can get right now.

Please help with your donations and prayers. Together we can make little Eloy get better. God bless

story:
UVCCLEANS Mask Box

Handheld Mode as a UVC wand

The Built-in Magnets make the UVCCLEANS Anywhere

The UV-C power testing showed the power of the UV-C light is 4630μW/cm². This UV-C light power is strong enough to sterilize just in seconds.

UVCcleans Mask Box is designed and manufactured by UVCcleans team. UVCcleans team made a lot of UVC products and designed this new UVC light Box for everyday carry (EDC). The mission of the UVCcleans is to help people with the daily convenience. From the idea to mass production, the teams spend the best to make the perfect UVC product.

UVC Wave: 185nm

Charging Port: USB-C

Battery: 500 mAh

Weight: 110g

Disinfection Mode: 5 mins/ 15 mins

Dimensions: 155x77x23 mm/6.1"x3.03"x0.9"

What's in the Box

  • 1 X UVCCleans
  • 1 X Lanyard
  • 1 X USB-C Cable
  • 1 X User Manual
  • 4 X Magnet Metal Plate

Perk Fulfilment

To ensure timely reward delivery, we will ship rewards via insured postal service (DHL, FedEx, USPS) from fulfillment location in USA and China.

Timeline

  • November, 2019 - ID and Product Design
  • April, 2020 - Prototype and Testings
  • June, 2020, Indiegogo Launch
  • June, 2020, Toolings and Trial Run
  • July, 2020, Mass Production
  • September, 2020, Worldwide Shipping

Risks and Challenges

No project is without risk and challenges but we try to do our absolute best to minimize them. The UVCcleans that you see in the pictures and videos on this page is working prototype. We have done all the necessary preliminary work, but there is still plenty of work for us to do as we proceed with mass production. With your support we can bring UVCcleans to users worldwide and your contributions will make it possible for us to achieve economies of scale and keep our production costs low. We should deliver out rewards at the August 2020 as long as everything goes according to plan.

    FAQ

    • What shipping service we are using?
    • To ensure timely UVCcleans delivery, we will ship UVCcleans via insured postal service (DHL, FedEx, USPS) from fulfillment location in USA and China. Most of the perks will use Container shipping to ship to the destination country or city and then use the local post office or shipping services to get the UVCcleans to your home.

     

    • How long does it take to ship to our place?
    • We will ship it via Container. For US residents, it will take 20-30 days for standard shipping. For the EU, it will take 25-35 days for standard shipping, plus another 3-5 days for local delivery to your door by local shipping services.

     

    • Is there VAT, duties or fees related to shipping?
    • For container shipment order to US/EU/AU/CA area, we will pay the tax. Our courier had worked on dozens crowdfunding projects which went smoothly through fulfillment. Under our arrangement, it won't entail additional costs for you under most circumstances. Despite that, the fact we're shipping directly from China may still impose a chance for further inspection and determination by the customs. The VAT, duties and fees vary by country. Please message us about the specifics.

     

    • What's the warranty for UVCcleans?
    • UVCcleans provides a 12-month warranty on Indiegogo orders, same as retail.

     

    • When will the UVCcleans be delivered?
    • We have moved into the production stage and we will have the first 2000 units of UVCcleans ready around the second week of August. Then we will continue the mass production.

     

    • What is the return policy?
    • We have a 30-day return policy. If your UVCcleans is defective or a manufacturer error after opening, you can return it for a refund or exchange. However, if it is working properly, it cannot be returned once it is opened and used, due to potential cross-contamination issues. The UVCcleans does have a one year warranty for any issues you experience in the first 12 months.

The UVCcleans that you see in the pictures and videos on this page is working prototype. We have done all the necessary preliminary work, but there is still plenty of work for us to do as we proceed with mass production. With your support we can bring UVCcleans to users worldwide and your contributions will make it possible for us to achieve economies of scale and keep our production costs low. We should deliver out rewards at the August 2020 as long as everything goes according to plan.FAQ
What shipping service we are using?
To ensure timely UVCcleans delivery, we will ship UVCcleans via insured postal service (DHL, FedEx, USPS) from fulfillment location in USA and China. Most of the perks will use Container shipping to ship to the destination country or city and then use the local post office or shipping services to get the UVCcleans to your home.
 
How long does it take to ship to our place?
We will ship it via Container. For US residents, it will take 20-30 days for standard shipping. For the EU, it will take 25-35 days for standard shipping, plus another 3-5 days for local delivery to your door by local shipping services.
 
Is there VAT, duties or fees related to shipping?
For container shipment order to US/EU/AU/CA area, we will pay the tax. Our courier had worked on dozens crowdfunding projects which went smoothly through fulfillment. Under our arrangement, it won't entail additional costs for you under most circumstances. Despite that, the fact we're shipping directly from China may still impose a chance for further inspection and determination by the customs. The VAT, duties and fees vary by country. Please message us about the specifics.
 

What's the warranty for UVCcleans?

UVCcleans provides a 12-month warranty on Indiegogo orders, same as retail.
 

When will the UVCcleans be delivered?

We have moved into the production stage and we will have the first 2000 units of UVCcleans ready around the second week of August. Then we will continue the mass production.
 
What is the return policy?
We have a 30-day return policy. If your UVCcleans is defective or a manufacturer error after opening, you can return it for a refund or exchange. However, if it is working properly, it cannot be returned once it is opened and used, due to potential cross-contamination issues. The UVCcleans does have a one year warranty for any issues you experience in the first 12 months.

story:
Short Summary

Thomas A. Warner Running for a Cure. (www.tawrunningforacure.com) was established to raise awareness for Huntington's disease by incorporating my passion for running and my motivation to help find a cure for (HD). On May 1st, 2014 I will begin running across the country from San Diego, CA to Syracuse, NY - almost 3000 miles, teaming up with the Huntington's Disease Society of America Pacific West Region http://www.firstgiving.com/fundraiser/tomwarner/thomasawarnerrunningforacure 

   Huntington's Disease (HD) has made a huge impact on me, my family, and my life It is my intention to help raise awareness for this disease, 

   This run is in honor of the people I love who have suffered and continue to suffer from the effects of (HD).

- Louise (Angelino) Warner - My mother, who has been living with (HD) for over 15 years.

- Carol (Angelino) Miller - My aunt who passed away last May from complications arising from (HD).

- Kathleen O'Neill - My friend, Shannon and Erin Kristen O'Neil's mother, who was diagnosed in August of 2001.

- Adam Barnes and his family.

- My two brothers and their families as well as my seven Angelino cousin’s.

   I am also running in honor of all the families and caregivers who have dedicated their lives to support loved ones with (HD).

​ I've lived in San Diego for nearly six years and before that Orlando, FL and Syracuse, NY. I’m an avid runner and a few years ago I began thinking about what I could do to help my family with their current situation. Since I was a teenager, I've always wanted to run across the country, and at the time it was just an idea which I never thought could become a reality. But after seeing what my father has gone through by sacrificing his time and his life to take care of my beautiful mother for the last 12 years (they were high school sweethearts and have been married for over 40 years) and watching him work so hard keeping up with his masonry business and listening to his struggles, I knew I had to do something to help find a cure and raise awareness about (HD). This past April, I left my job as a branch manager for Sunbelt Rentals in San Diego and spent most of the summer in Syracuse helping my dad. I've decided now is the time to take action. In August I took my retirement savings to start this nonprofit, I decided to incorporate my love of running with my passion of finding a cure for this disease. The effects of (HD) on my family are countless and I know there are so many others in need of support and assistance; this is my goal and my vision for the future.


​ What We Need & What You Get

 In order for me to organize this run, (this will be the first run across the country for raising awareness for Huntington’s disease ) I need your support!  Without your support this run will not be possible! I am looking for donations and sponsors to help me with the funding with a goal of $570,000 that will be allocated as follows: 

I will be raising/donating $150,000 for the Huntington's Disease Society of America that will go towards continued research for helping the HDSA find a cure for which affects 1 in 10,0000 people in the US. Check out my HDSA fund raising page at: http://www.firstgiving.com/fundraiser/tomwarner/thomasawarnerrunningforacure 

The rest of the donations & sponsorship's will be going towards setting up grants for the Thomas A Warner Running For A Cure Nonprofit to help families currently affected by (HD) and are in financial need. And to support this 2850 mile run that will be raising awareness for (HD). I am in need of funding for the following: 

- RV either by donation or renting 

- Gas/Diesel (Donations, by gas cards, gift cards or funds) 

- Support Team (looking to hire 2 to 3 people to come along on this journey) 

- My Workouts & Training  (which takes up 3 to 6 hours a day) 

- Food & Supplies (looking for sponsors, gift cards, or funds) 

- Clothing (looking for sponsors, gift cards, or funds)

For more information about sponsorship opportunities or if you would like to sponsor please contact me at xrun@tawrunningforacure.com or call me at 619-200-6244

 I've started training for this 2850 mile run by incorporating the Beach Body workout “Insanity” as well as running the San Diego Convention Center stairs, and training runs throughout the week.  I am currently working out 3 to 4 hours a day and will increase my workouts to 5 to 6 hours a day in the next few months, by adding swimming and yoga to my workout schedule which you can follow on my website www.tawrunningforacure.com or via my Tumblr blog http://www.tumblr.com/blog/tawrunningforacure,  In the next few months, I hope to hire a few people to help me organize and plan, as well as join me on this journey to help keep me focused as I run 26 or more miles a day from coast to coast. I will be documenting this run as well, using live camera feeds and pictures, posting on my website, Facebook, and Instagram. 

I will raise these funds through sponsors, advertisers and donations. And will be holding events with the help of these sponsors and the HDSA to continue to raise awareness for HD. Thank you for your support! 

I am fully dedicated to my nonprofit and this run, for I would not have invested my time, my retirement, my job and my body for raising awareness and helping to find a cure for Huntington’s.  Please join me in touching the lives of HD victims and families who have already given theirs for those they love.  Let’s cure Huntington's disease together!


The Impact

 

I will be running a marathon for almost 109 consecutive days to reach my destination of Syracuse, NY- totaling 2850 miles by August 17th 2014. The purpose of this run is to help the continued efforts of researcher's and the Huntington's Disease Society of America in finding a cure for Huntington's Disease (HD). My family and I have felt the impact of this disease first hand with both my mother who is terminally ill, wheel chair bound and needs full time care, given by my father, Tom and my Aunt Sandy. It also affected my Aunt Carol, my mother's older sister, who passed away from (HD) complications in a nursing home last year. My brothers Ed and Bob, as well as myself, my cousins Debbie and Carolyn, (my Aunt Carol’s daughters), my Uncle’s Bobby and Eddie’s children, Jaclyn, Kristine, Caitlyn, Marisa, and Kris as well as my friend Shannon, whose mother has (HD) and is currently in a caregiver home in San Diego, and my friend and old college roommate Adam, whose mother just found out she has (HD). All of us have a fifty percent chance of inheriting this genetic disease. This has caused some of us to be tested to see if we carry the (HD) gene, which affects long term decisions, such as having children.

​  My vision for the future for my nonprofit, and after I have finished my run across the country, is to keep raising awareness for (HD) and to help find a cure for this hereditary terminal illness which devastates so many. I will do this by coordinating marathons and fundraisers throughout the country with the support of local (HD) groups and the HDSA, by encouraging a health conscious environment and promoting an “All In” approach for the sake of body, mind and soul in which I believe creates a positive attitude towards life and supports people coping with the difficulties families affected by (HD) face on a daily basis.

   I have yet to determine if I will be tested for Huntington's disease before or after the run, or if I will even get tested at all to see if I carry the (HD) gene. What I do know is that I'm ready to take on the challenge and live life to the fullest by dedicating my time and efforts into what I know will leave a positive impression on my family and those affected by Huntington's disease.

story:
Get Wayne Necessary Medical Attention and Rehabilitation in Belize

Wayne, an intelligent hard-working man, was tragically paralyzed two years ago in a car accident in Belize, and needs immediate support to provide a foundation for living and healing so he may regain a meaningful life. His third-world living conditions are unsafe, he is malnourished, has received no rehabilitation, needs medical attention, supplies, equipment, and a trained caregiver.

We are raising funds for our Belizean friend Wayne Coleman in Dangriga, Belize. We are “Wayne’s Team”, and with Bahá’í friends in three countries, we created this campaign to ask for contributions which are vital for Wayne. Each of us knows Wayne from working or vacationing in Belize. (Watch video #1, Canadian team members with Wayne: https://vimeo.com/100344568)

                                      What Wayne Needs Now

Wayne has consumed his meager savings and all governmental support, so we are asking for YOUR support. He needs financial support for at least one year.

Total Amount Requested is $25,400 USD:

  • $600 for monthly living expenses (food, utilities, transportation, yard, etc)
  • $400 for local caregiver’s monthly salary (care required up to 24/7)
  • $4,000 to send and support US Registered Nurse Judi Behrendt to Belize for 2 months to train local caregiver, and to arrange for Wayne’s needed medical attention and surgery to graft skin onto large, dangerous, long-standing bedsores (we promised to pay her expenses: airfare, in-country travel, rent, food, visa)
  • $125 monthly, approximately, for medical consumables (MD visits, sterile gloves, bandages, ointments, etc)
  • $4,100 to repay just one-half of Wayne’s two hospitalizations in May and July 2014 which were paid for in full by early contributors
  • $2,000 for non-consumables: bed linens, mattress overlay, over-bed trapeze for strength building and to aid movement, etc.
  • $300 for electrical supplies to re-wire his unsafe house (the labor will be donated)
  • $1,500 for structural repairs to his wooden house (to keep the rain from raining on the inside!)
  • He also needs an electric wheelchair, and an electric hospital bed so he can live more independently. (We have not included these items in the total – but he needs them.)

                                      The IMPACT on Wayne’s Life!

  • Six weeks ago Wayne’s bedsores were surgically cleaned and prepared for grafting
  • The US Registered Nurse arrived in June and with eyes on the ground assessed his medical, living conditions, needs, and made recommendations
  • One week ago all three of his bedsores – which could not have healed by themselves – were successfully skin grafted in a Belizean hospital! This is amazing progress in record time, and now he must heal by spending the majority of his time on his stomach for at least 2 weeks so as not to irritate the surgical repairs
  • It is essential for Wayne to eat an appropriate, high protein diet to heal - which increases his food expenses
  • The electrical hazards in his simple house must be eliminated, and lighting added to dark rooms so his caregiver can function properly
  • House rotten wood must be replaced, other structural repairs completed, and the outside weatherproofed.

About Wayne: until 2012 Wayne was a vegetable vendor at the open air Central Market in Dangriga where he sold produce. While driving to Belmopan to purchase product one evening he skidded off the wet road and suffered a nearly fatal accident. At the hospital, his spinal cord was found to be severed leaving the lower half of his body paralyzed, and his legs crushed.  After initial surgeries in multiple government hospitals Wayne continues to be bedridden which resulted in large, deep pressure sores and upper body weakness. He is also prone to infections and seizures. 

He has had difficulty getting effective long-term medical care. His caregiver is willing but untrained, but access to medical equipment and supplies is difficult, limited, and expensive. He has consumed his financial resources, and needs sound guidance in the management of his long-term care. His condition is most challenging in Belize where access to specialized medical resources and attention is available only to those who are exceptionally fortunate or who can travel abroad.

Wayne lives in a simple wooden house which he built himself and is without air conditioning or indoor plumbing. He cannot get out of bed by himself, has an indwelling catheter and dangerous bedsores due to his lack of consistent care and proper nutrition. Prior to receiving a standard hospital bed a few weeks ago, he lived on a narrow, flat, old-fashioned hospital gurney with a pad which promoted the development of his pressure sores. He sometimes cooks simple food on his bedside hot plate.

He recently received a kind contribution of a laptop and a year’s internet service which connects him to the world! Prior to this, news of his condition was sporadic. He is hopeful that one day he may be employed via the internet. (Watch video #2, Wayne is presented with the gift of a laptop: https://vimeo.com/100348267)

Wayne faces his ordeals with patience, ordeals which might drive many of us into hopelessness and despair. We might ask ourselves how we might react after losing our independence, being bedridden and unable to take care of ourselves? Wayne is a man of strong Faith, he reads and prays regularly. Wayne is an educated and intelligent man who is aware of his long-term health needs and is eager to learn how to manage them with the help of God and his friends. His positive spirit is not letting this get him down!

Please help us raise money for Wayne. Be a contributor!

If this is practical for you please make contributions via PayPal (instead of by credit card) because the funds are received immediately and result in lesser charges we need to pay.

If you live in Canada and prefer making a contribution by cheque, please contact Bob at rleblanc195@gmail.com .

If you live in the USA and prefer making a contribution by check, please contact Cher at WayneBelizeTeam@gmail.com .

                                    Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • PLEASE spread the word and make some noise about our campaign. We would love it if you would share this with everyone you know in your family, school, church, and community!
  • Please remember Wayne and this effort in your thoughts and prayers.
  • Indiegogo has sharing tools - share on Facebook, through email, Twitter.

                                     How Will All of This Be Managed?

Funds will be held in a separate US account and used only for Wayne’s benefit. Funds will be disbursed for monthly expenses, and as needed to make one-time purchases. Cher will be accountable to Wayne’s Team for the disbursement and accounting of all funds for as long as they last. Wayne’s Team is a collection of professionals who are also personal friends committed to this endeavor.

Lovingly and with Great Appreciation, Wayne's Team

#WayneBelizeTeam


Hello All:
Wayne writes poetry and here is one of them:

THE SAME OLD BENCH  

 I saw you look for me then you shake your head.  Wondering where did I go?  

I am still here sitting on the same old bench, watching the Passers by chit- chatting as they trod along.  Some greet me with a smile.  

Others say hi, hello, how are you today?  

Above my head under this magnificent, flamboyant tree, as I Sat gazing into the horizon I heard the beautiful sound of a Lark. She sang with such a sweet refrain.  

Melodiously she harmonized with the same serenity that I felt Inside, making me feel good to be alive.  

Sitting here, resting my bones pondering on the issues of Life, searching for solutions,  

My mind reflects on some of yesteryear’s wise saying:

“Knowledge hidden from the wise and prudent will be Revealed to the babe and sucklings,- the pure of heart.”

 So for reasons more than one,

When you pass this way looking for me, 

Don't be amazed if you find me here,

Sitting on this same old bench

Watching the passers- by.  Sometimes you might even catch me gazing into the sky

On this, same old bench.
